source: Transfer Pricing Rules in the Philippines — BIR RR 2-2013, RR 34-2020

chunks.title: Legal Basis: NIRC Section 50 — Allocation of Income and Deductions
chunks.content: The legal foundation for transfer pricing in the Philippines is Section 50 of the National Internal Revenue Code (NIRC), which grants the Commissioner of Internal Revenue the authority to distribute, apportion, or allocate gross income or deductions between or among organizations, trades, or businesses owned or controlled directly or indirectly by the same interests, if such distribution, apportionment, or allocation is necessary to prevent evasion of taxes or to clearly reflect the income of any such organizations. This provision applies to both domestic and cross-border transactions involving related parties. Revenue Regulations No. 2-2013 implemented Section 50 by adopting the arm's length principle as the standard for determining whether related party transactions (RPTs) are priced correctly. RR 2-2013 explicitly references the OECD Transfer Pricing Guidelines as the interpretive framework, making the Philippines broadly aligned with international transfer pricing standards. Revenue Regulations No. 34-2020 subsequently expanded the documentation and reporting requirements, introducing BIR Form 1709 and mandating contemporaneous transfer pricing documentation. The BIR has also issued Revenue Memorandum Circular (RMC) 44-2020 providing guidance on the new form and documentation requirements.

chunks.title: Arm's Length Principle and OECD Guidelines Adoption
chunks.content: The arm's length principle is the international standard for pricing transactions between related parties. It requires that the conditions (including price) of transactions between associated enterprises be consistent with those that would be agreed upon between independent enterprises in comparable transactions under comparable circumstances. The Philippines adopted the OECD Transfer Pricing Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and Tax Administrations as the primary reference for applying the arm's length principle. Under this framework: (1) the controlled transaction between related parties is identified and characterized; (2) comparable uncontrolled transactions (CUTs) are sought — either internal comparables (transactions between the taxpayer and unrelated parties) or external comparables (transactions between third parties in similar circumstances); (3) the most appropriate transfer pricing method is selected; (4) the arm's length range is determined using the comparables; (5) the related party transaction price is tested against the arm's length range. If the price falls outside the arm's length range, the BIR may adjust the taxable income of one or both related parties. The burden of proof is on the taxpayer to demonstrate that their intercompany pricing is arm's length, supported by contemporaneous documentation.

chunks.title: Related Party Definition
chunks.content: Under RR 2-2013 and RR 34-2020, related parties (associated enterprises) include: (1) Enterprises where one entity directly or indirectly participates in the management, control, or capital of the other — typically 50% or more ownership (voting shares or profit entitlement); (2) Enterprises where the same persons directly or indirectly participate in the management, control, or capital of both enterprises (common control); (3) Members of the same group of companies, including parent-subsidiary relationships and sister companies; (4) An enterprise and a permanent establishment (PE) of another enterprise; (5) Related individuals — persons related within the fourth civil degree of consanguinity or affinity, and their associated enterprises; (6) A trust or estate and its beneficiaries, trustees, or grantors; (7) Partnerships and their partners. The definition is broad and looks at both direct and indirect control. Indirect control includes control through intermediary entities, nominees, or agents. Special attention is given to: (a) management control — even without equity ownership, if one entity effectively controls the other's strategic decisions; (b) financial dependence — if one entity is financially dependent on the other for its operations. BIR Form 1709 requires disclosure of the specific nature of the related party relationship for each reported transaction.

chunks.title: Transfer Pricing Methods — Hierarchy and Application
chunks.content: RR 2-2013 prescribes the following transfer pricing methods, generally following the OECD hierarchy: (1) Comparable Uncontrolled Price (CUP) Method — compares the price in the controlled transaction to the price in a comparable uncontrolled transaction. Most direct and preferred when reliable comparables exist. Commonly used for commodity transactions, interest rates, and royalties; (2) Resale Price Method (RPM) — starts with the price at which a product purchased from a related party is resold to an unrelated party, then subtracts an appropriate gross margin (comparable resale margin). Used for distribution activities with limited value-add; (3) Cost Plus Method (CPM) — starts with the costs incurred by the supplier in the related party transaction, then adds an appropriate cost-plus markup (comparable markup). Used for manufacturing, toll processing, and service arrangements; (4) Transactional Net Margin Method (TNMM) — examines the net profit margin of a related party relative to an appropriate base (costs, sales, or assets) and compares it with net margins of comparable independent parties. Most commonly used method in practice due to availability of comparable data; (5) Profit Split Method (PSM) — allocates combined profits of related parties based on their respective contributions (functions, assets, risks). Used for highly integrated operations or unique intangibles. The taxpayer should select the most appropriate method based on the nature of the transaction, availability of comparable data, and functional analysis.

chunks.title: Documentation Requirements Under RR 34-2020 and BIR Form 1709
chunks.content: RR 34-2020 significantly expanded transfer pricing documentation requirements effective 2020. The key requirements are: (1) BIR Form 1709 — Related Party Transactions (RPT) Form General Information Sheet — must be filed annually as an attachment to the income tax return (BIR Form 1702 for corporations, 1701 for individuals). The form requires: list of all related parties, nature of relationship, description of each RPT, amounts, transfer pricing method used, and whether documentation is maintained. Failure to file Form 1709 is subject to penalties under Section 250 of the NIRC (PHP 10,000 fine per failure); (2) Transfer Pricing Documentation (Local File) — a comprehensive document that includes: (a) organizational structure, (b) description of the business and industry, (c) functional analysis (functions performed, assets used, risks assumed by each party), (d) description of each RPT and its terms, (e) selection of transfer pricing method with justification, (f) comparable analysis with search methodology, (g) financial data and analysis, (h) conclusion on arm's length compliance. The local file must be prepared contemporaneously (at the time of the transaction or no later than the filing of the annual ITR); (3) Master File — recommended (but not yet mandatory) for groups of companies with multiple jurisdictions, containing group-level information following OECD BEPS Action 13 (CbC reporting framework). The Philippines has signed the Multilateral Competent Authority Agreement (MCAA) for Country-by-Country Reporting.

chunks.title: BIR Adjustment Powers and Penalties for Non-Compliance
chunks.content: The BIR has broad powers to adjust transfer prices that do not comply with the arm's length principle. Under Section 50 of the NIRC: (1) Primary Adjustment — the BIR may reallocate income by adjusting the price of the controlled transaction to the arm's length price. This results in additional taxable income for the Philippine entity; (2) Corresponding Adjustment — the related party in the other jurisdiction may seek a corresponding adjustment to avoid double taxation (through MAP or domestic relief); (3) Secondary Adjustment — the BIR may recharacterize the excess payment as a constructive dividend, deemed loan, or other form of income distribution. Penalties for non-compliance: (a) 25% surcharge on the deficiency tax resulting from transfer pricing adjustments (Section 248); (b) 12% annual interest on the deficiency (Section 249 as amended by TRAIN); (c) compromise penalty per RMO 7-2015; (d) criminal penalties under Section 254 (attempt to evade tax) if the BIR can demonstrate willful intent to manipulate transfer prices; (e) penalties for failure to file BIR Form 1709 — PHP 10,000 per failure (Section 250); (f) penalties for failure to maintain contemporaneous documentation — the BIR may reject the taxpayer's pricing methodology and apply its own. Additionally, the burden of proof shifts to the BIR for adjustments exceeding the amounts reported by the taxpayer, but the absence of documentation makes it significantly easier for the BIR to sustain an assessment.

chunks.title: Advance Pricing Agreements (APA)
chunks.content: An Advance Pricing Agreement (APA) is a binding agreement between a taxpayer and one or more tax authorities that determines, in advance, the transfer pricing methodology for a set of future related party transactions over a fixed period. The Philippines allows APAs under RR 2-2013. Types: (1) Unilateral APA — agreement between the taxpayer and the BIR only. Provides certainty with the Philippine tax authority but does not bind the foreign tax authority, so the risk of double taxation remains; (2) Bilateral APA — agreement between the taxpayer, the BIR, and the competent authority of the other jurisdiction. Provides certainty in both countries and eliminates double taxation risk. Requires an existing tax treaty with a MAP provision; (3) Multilateral APA — involves three or more tax authorities, used for complex MNE structures. The APA application process: (a) Pre-filing consultation — informal and confidential discussion with BIR to assess feasibility; (b) Formal application — submission of detailed documentation including functional analysis, proposed methodology, financial projections, and comparable analysis; (c) BIR evaluation — review and analysis of the application, potential site visits and interviews; (d) Negotiation and agreement — the BIR and taxpayer (and foreign authority for bilateral APAs) negotiate the terms; (e) Annual compliance reporting — the taxpayer must demonstrate annual compliance with APA terms. Typical APA coverage period is 3-5 years, with possible rollback to prior years. Processing time can be 1-3 years.

chunks.title: Thin Capitalization and Interest Limitation
chunks.content: While the Philippines does not have a formal thin capitalization rule in the NIRC, the BIR may challenge excessive intercompany debt and reclassify interest payments as dividends under the following mechanisms: (1) Section 50 (arm's length principle) — if the debt-to-equity ratio between related parties is not consistent with what independent parties would agree to, the BIR can recharacterize the excess debt as equity, disallowing interest deductions and treating payments as non-deductible dividends subject to withholding tax; (2) Section 34(B)(1) — interest expense deduction is subject to a reduction equal to 20% of interest income earned (previously 33% pre-TRAIN). This limits the net interest deduction; (3) The OECD BEPS Action 4 recommendations on interest limitation have not yet been formally adopted in Philippine legislation, but the BIR is monitoring developments and may introduce specific thin capitalization rules in the future; (4) In practice, the BIR examines: debt-to-equity ratio (benchmarked against industry standards, though no statutory safe harbor exists), whether the loan terms are arm's length (interest rate, tenor, collateral, covenants), the ability of the borrower to service the debt independently, and whether the funding was really equity disguised as debt. For intercompany loans, the interest rate must be benchmarked against arm's length rates, considering the borrower's credit profile, loan currency, tenor, and security. Common benchmarks include BVAL (Bloomberg Valuation) rates, BSP overnight lending rate, and comparable third-party loan databases.

chunks.title: Common Related Party Transaction Issues
chunks.content: The most frequently scrutinized related party transactions in BIR audits include: (1) Management Fees — charges by a parent company or regional headquarters for management, technical, or administrative services. The BIR challenges these when: services cannot be documented, the fee structure is not arm's length, the services are mere shareholder activities (benefit the parent, not the subsidiary), or duplicate services already available locally. Documentation must include service agreements, time records, deliverables, and benefit tests; (2) Intercompany Loans — the BIR examines whether the interest rate, terms, and conditions are arm's length. Key issues: absence of formal loan agreements, no collateral or covenants, interest-free loans (deemed to have taxable benefit), and back-to-back loans indicating conduit arrangements; (3) Royalties and License Fees — payments for use of intangibles (trademarks, patents, technology). BIR issues: inflated royalty rates, payment for intangibles with no demonstrable value to the Philippine entity, and improper allocation of R&D costs; (4) Cost-Sharing Arrangements — agreements to share costs and risks of developing intangibles. The BIR examines whether participants are sharing costs in proportion to expected benefits and whether buy-in/buy-out payments are arm's length; (5) Guarantee Fees — charges for parent company guarantees on subsidiary debt. Must be priced at arm's length considering the benefit to the subsidiary (lower interest rate due to guarantee).
